thread.title: The Morning Download: AI Is Only as Good as the Data You Feed It

author: Kim S. Nash
title: The Morning Download: AI Is Only as Good as the Data You Feed It
text:
0 COMMENTS A screenshot of the Virtual Analytics Workbench tool, developed by Pfizer and vendors including Alation Inc. Photo: Alation Inc.
Sign up here for The Morning Download, and get the most important news in business technology emailed to you each weekday morning. Subscribe to WSJ Pro Cybersecurity for in-depth coverage on cybersecurity trends, breaches and best practices. Good morning, CIOs. Artificial intelligence can’t replace your doctor yet but it can help diagnose illness. Pfizer Inc. is expanding its AI-enabled analytics toolset to catch diseases that are easy to miss because they’re rare or disguised by other illnesses a patient may have. The cloud-based system, called Virtual Analytics Workbench, brings together physicians notes, lab reports, demographics and other patient particulars, as CIO Journal’s Sara Castellanos reports .
Health care presents exciting opportunities to apply AI, but we’re still far from Dr. McCoy’s tricorder instant diagnostic device on Star Trek. One obstacle slowing AI’s progress generally is a lack of suitable data with which to train algorithms, according to Kate Crawford, a distinguished research professor at New York University and a principal researcher at Microsoft Research New York, She spoke at the WSJ Future of Everything Festival​ this week . Too much AI training data is too narrow. Wide swaths are needed to create algorithms free of bias, she said
Selective crowdsourcing could help. The University of California, San Francisco is asking women to donate their mammogram images and text data to a web portal where scientists are crowdsourcing research to accelerate the development of better tests for early detection, as Dexter Hadley, a genomics and computational biology expert at UCSF, recently told CIO Journal.
Benioff: MuleSoft purchase ‘critical’ to Salesforce strategy. Salesforce.com Inc .’s $6.5 billion acquisition of MuleSoft was driven by a growing demand among enterprises to better integrate business applications and data locked within their systems, Salesforce Chief Executive Marc Benioff says. “This has always been a great match, because our two platforms are stronger together, they’re better together,” Mr. Benioff said in remarks about the deal, which closed last week. CIO Journal’s Angus Loten has more .
Today’s internet weather: Cloud-y. Beyond targeted cyberattacks, one of the biggest challenges that chief information officers face is the volatility of the internet, said Kyle York, the general manager and vice president of business and product strategy for the Oracle Corp. Dyn Global Business Unit. CIO Journal’s Angus Loten reports that the company in June plans to reclease an “Internet Weather Map” aimed at helping businesses better anticipate latency issues and outages.
TECHNOLOGY NEWS
ZTE Corp. was hit with a sales ban in April after the Commerce Department said the Chinese telecommunications-equipment company violated the terms of a deal last year settling allegations of sanctions busting involving North Korea and Iran. Photo: CHINATOPIX/ASSOCIATED PRESS
ZTE says it halted major operations following U.S. sales ban. The Shenzhen-based telecommunications company disclosed in a regulatory filing Wednesday that “major operating activities of the Company have ceased.” The announcement came less than a month after the U.S. Commerce Department banned American companies from selling components to ZTE Corp. The Journal’s Dan Strumpf has more .
World’s biggest tech fund’s pace exceeds ambitious vision. As of the end of March, the Vision Fund and a smaller affiliate run by Japan’s SoftBank Group Corp. had invested around $30 billion of their nearly $100 billion in committed capital, the WSJ’s Phred Dvorak and Mayumi Negishi report .
Jobs site snapped up by Tokyo-based HR firm. Online jobs portal Glassdoor Inc. said has agreed to be bought by Japan’s Recruit Holdings Co. for $1.2 billion in an all-cash deal, the WSJ reports .
Will Iran’s cyberattacks increase? With the U.S. moving to unilaterally break a 2015 nuclear deal, experts anticipate more cyber activity from Iran.”They’ve developed this ability over the last years and there’s no reason for them not to use it now,” Levi Gundert, analyst at intelligence firm Recorded Future , tells Wired .
U.S. safety investigators examine another fatal Tesla crash. The National Transportation Safety Board will examine a fiery crash of a Tesla Inc. Model S car that killed two teenagers in Fort Lauderdale, Florida Tuesday. The WSJ’s Arian Campo-Flores and Tim Higgins report that the agency doesn’t anticipate Tesla’s driver-assistance system Autopilot being part of the investigation.
White House to discuss future of AI. The White House on Thursday will host a meeting on artificial intelligence with leaders from Silicon Valley and representatives from various federal agencies expected to take part, the WSJ’s John D. McKinnon reports . Expected participants include Intel Corp. CEO Brian Krzanich and the CTOs of Ford Motor Co. and Boeing Co.
Companies named for U.S. drone program . The U.S. Transportation Department on Wednesday announced 10 drone projects to help determine regulation, Reuters reports . The projects include efforts from Apple Inc ., FedEx Corp. , Microsoft Corp. and startup Flirtey , which will deliver medicne to heart attack victims in Nevada, Reuters says. Missing from the list: Amazon.com Inc. delivery drones.
THE FUTURE OF EVERYTHING
NewDealDesign founder Gadi Amit said eliminating cash could affect how—and how much—people spend. Photo: PRODUCTIONMANAGER.COM
Jetpacks and tech-enabled cities: How we’ll live in the future. Innovators are spinning transportation forward, cities are using data to get smarter and payments are getting digital. Experts at WSJ’s Future of Everything Festival talk about the consequences, good and bad.
Less meat, more veggies. At Row7 Seed Company , chef Dan Barber and breeder Michael Mazourek are deploying plant genealogy, computer modeling and field sensors to create flavor-packed vegetables.
Less state, more city. “You basically have the atrophying of the nation-state and the emergence of the city-state,” said Chicago Mayor Rahm Emanuel.
Less cash, more digital payments. Dan Schulman, president and chief executive of payments company PayPal Holdings Inc., believes digital payments will become an ever-larger industry, with many key players.
EVERYTHING ELSE YOU NEED TO KNOW
China likely will offer to import more U.S. goods during negotiations in Washington next week as the two sides see one of the best ways to avert an all-out trade war is for Beijing to buy American. (WSJ)
California took a major step Wednesday toward becoming the first state to require solar panels on nearly all new homes. (WSJ)
European stocks showed signs of stalling after four sessions of gains, with many investors looking ahead to an update from the Bank of England later in the day. (WSJ)
Trump lawyer Michael Cohen’s firm Essential Consultants has evolved into a nexus in federal investigations buffeting the Trump administration. (WSJ)
ABOUT US
The Morning Download is edited by Tom Loftus and cues up the most important news in business technology every weekday morning. You can get The Morning Download emailed to you each weekday morning by clicking http://wsj.com/TheMorningDownload .
